docs.title: Blackboard QA Automation
docs.text: Welcome to the Blackboard QA Automation documentation site.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: If you are new to the team, please start with the QA Onboarding Guide.

docs.title: Documentation Sections
docs.text:
• QA Onboarding Guide: Your manual for getting started as a QA Analyst.
  • QA Protocols: The core rules and standards for our courses.
  • Student QA Checklist: The step-by-step checklist for verifying courses.

docs.title: Manual QA Onboarding Guide
docs.text: Welcome to the team! This guide is designed to help you get started as a Manual Quality Assurance (QA) Analyst. Your role is critical in ensuring our Blackboard Ultra courses are error-free, consistent, and user-friendly for students.

docs.title: 1. What is Software Quality Assurance (SQA)?
docs.text: Software Quality Assurance (SQA) is the process of verifying that a product meets all requirements and quality standards. As a Manual QA Analyst, you are the last line of defense before a course goes live to students or faculty.

docs.title: Core Principles for Manual QA
docs.text:
1. Think Like a User: Always navigate the course as a student would. If it's confusing to you, it will be confusing to them.
  2. Attention to Detail: Small errors (broken links, typos, wrong dates) can majorly impact the user experience.
  3. Consistency: Courses should feel familiar. Use the protocols to ensure every course follows the same structure.

docs.title: Your Responsibilities
docs.text:
• Verification: Manually checking course pages against our checklists.
  • Validation: Ensuring features work as intended (e.g., clicking links, checking start dates).
  • Reporting: Clearly documenting any issues you find so they can be fixed.

docs.title: 2. Project Overview: Blackboard Course Verification
docs.text: Our goal is to ensure every Blackboard Ultra course shell is "Student Ready" and "Instructor Ready". We check for structural integrity, content accuracy, and compliance with our standards.

docs.title: Key Documents You Will Use
docs.text:
• QA Protocols: The "Rule Book". This document explains what makes a course correct (e.g., naming conventions, required modules, accessibility rules).
  • Student QA Checklist: The "Scorecard". This is the specific list of items you must check for every course (e.g., "Is the Syllabus link working?", "Is Module 1 visible?").

docs.title: 3. The QA Process
docs.text: Your daily workflow will typically involve the following steps:

docs.title: Step 1: Access the Course
docs.text: Log in to Blackboard and navigate to the course shell you are assigned to review.

docs.title: Step 2: "Student View" Review
docs.text: Most of your testing should be done using the Student Preview mode in Blackboard. This ensures you see exactly what a student sees (hiding instructor-only files, grade center columns, etc.).

docs.title: Step 3: Run the Checklist
docs.text: Open the Student QA Checklist and methodically go through each section: 1. Course Info & Orientation: Check the Banner, Syllabus link, and Start Here module. 2. Modules & Navigation: Ensure all modules are visible and logical. 3. Content Checks: Open assignments and discussions. Check for broken links, clear instructions, and attached rubrics.

docs.title: Step 4: Verify "release" conditions
docs.text: Ensure that content meant to be hidden until a certain date is actually hidden, and content meant to be visible is visible.

docs.title: Step 5: Accessibility Spot Check
docs.text:
• Do images have descriptions (Alt text)?
  • Are headers used correctly in text (H1, H2)?
  • Is the contrast readable?

docs.title: Step 6: Reporting Issues
docs.text: When you find a bug (e.g., a broken link, a missing rubric, a typo): 1. Document it: Note the Course ID, the specific location (e.g., "Module 1 > Assignment 2"), and the issue. 2. Tag it: User standard tags if you are logging into a system (e.g., #BrokenLink, #GrammarIssue). 3. Be Clear: Write the issue so that anyone reading it knows exactly how to find and fix it. * Bad: "Link broken." * Good: "In 'Module 1 Overview', the link to 'Article 1' leads to a 404 error page."

docs.title: 4. Common Issues to Watch For
docs.text:
• Placeholder Text: Look for text like "Insert content here" or generic dates like "1/1/2035".
  • Raw URLs: We want descriptive links (e.g., "Click here for the article"), not raw web addresses (e.g., https://www.google.com...).
  • Permissions: Ensure files attached from Google Drive or SharePoint are actually shareable with students.
  • Gradebook: Check that grade columns match the assignments listed in the syllabus.

docs.title: 5. Tools & Resources
docs.text:
While your work is primarily manual, we have automated tools that run nightly to catch some errors. You may see reports from these tools. * LanguageTool Reports: Highlight potential grammar and spelling mistakes. * Link Checkers: Automated lists of broken links.

Use these reports to guide your manual review, but always verify the findings yourself.

Questions? Reach out to the Lead QA or refer to the qa_protocols.md for deep dives into specific rules.

  2. "Make sure the banner image matches the course code and title."
  3. Syllabus Resource (Radio)

  5. Header Info (TDAC) (Radio)
  6. "Verify that the header contains the correct class code and name..."
  7. Syllabus Links (Radio)

  11. Syllabus Format (Radio)

    • "All Module Release Conditions are correctly set up..."
  2. Raw Links (Radio)
    • "Make sure there are no raw links placed in any Blackboard page. Except for ATI resources."
    • Note: Automation may need to select "Raw links were found" if "No raw links" is unclickable.
  3. Learning Materials Links (Radio)
    • "Make sure all links in the 'Learning Materials' module work. This includes video links and LTI links."

docs.title: Page 5: Assignments

1. Has Assignments? (Radio)

docs.title: Page 10: Wrap-up
docs.text:
1. Tracking List Update (Radio)
    • "Add your findings to the Microsoft tracking list." -> Action: Select "Done"

    • "Add time spent on QA..." -> Action: Enter time string (e.g., "QA time: 15 mins")

    • "Change the Microsoft tracking list status to 'SQA findings'" -> Action: Select "Done."

  2. Action: Enter the course ID (e.g., "TRACY").
  3. Microsoft tracking list status (Radio)
  4. Question: "In the Microsoft tracking list for the program, change the status to the 'Under Post-Sync QA' tag."

docs.title: Page 2: LTIs
docs.text:
1. LTI Links (Radio)
  2. Question: "The course has the required LTIs and all links work correctly. Please use the TeacherQA account and activate 'Student Preview' to test the links."
  3. Action: Select "Correct" (or "Incorrect. Documented" if issues found).

docs.title: Page 3: Respondus
docs.text:
1. Respondus Activation (Radio)
  2. Question: "Respondus is activated for the course."
  3. Action: Select "Done" (or "N/A").

docs.title: Page 4: TDAC Due dates
docs.text:
1. Due Dates (Radio)
  2. Question: "The due dates are adjusted for all assessments."
  3. Action: Select "Done" (or "N/A").

docs.title: Page 5: Gradebook
docs.text:
1. Grade Distribution (Radio)
  2. Question: "The overall grade distribution matches the syllabus."
  3. Action: Select "The overall grade distribution matches the syllabus" (or "In at least one assessment...").
  4. Gradebook Sorting (Radio)
  5. Question: "All items in the Gradebook are sorted correctly. The Final Grade, Overall Grade and the Course Orientation acknowledgement must be the first items on the list, followed by the module activities in consecutive order."
  6. Action: Select "All items in the Gradebook are sorted correctly" (or "At least one item...").
  7. Grade Schema (Radio)
  8. Question: "Make sure the grade schema 'Pacific College Letter' matches the following parameters:"
  9. Action: Select "All the indications above are met" (or "One or more indications...").

docs.title: Page 6: Wrap-Up
docs.text:
1. Time Spent (Text) (Wait, prompt says "Add time spent... (Radio: Done)" but usually time is text. Prompt says: "Add time spent on QA as a comment in the SharePoint list: PSQA time: 1h 40m (Radio: Done)". Ah, it asks to add the comment in SharePoint, then click Done in the form?
  2. Re-reading prompt: "Add time spent on QA as a comment in the SharePoint list: PSQA time: 1h 40m (Radio: Done)" -> It seems the question on the form is asking if you did this action. It's a Radio button "Done".
  3. Correction: The prompt says "Total: 10 questions". Let's count.
    1. Course code (Text)
    2. Status change (Radio)
    3. LTIs (Radio)
    4. Respondus (Radio)
    5. Due dates (Radio)
    6. Grade dist (Radio)
    7. Sorting (Radio)
    8. Schema (Radio)
    9. Time spent (Radio: Done) - The prompt implies the question is "Did you add the time?".
    10. Status change findings (Radio: Done)

  4. Okay, that matches 10 questions.

  5. Final Status Change (Radio)

    • Question: "In the Microsoft list of the program, change the status to Post-Sync QA Findings and add the findings link."
    • Action: Select "Done".

docs.title: LMS QA Protocols and Guidelines
docs.text: (Source: https://lmsknowledgebase.miraheze.org/wiki/Main_Page)

docs.title: 🎓 Welcome
docs.text: Purpose: Standardize QA processes and ensure consistent course quality across departments and modalities.

docs.title: ✅ SQA – Standard QA
docs.text:
• When: After TQA, before the live term
  • Purpose: Confirm consistency across sections/shells and validate applied changes
  • Scope: content accuracy; grading schema; assessments/rubrics; schedule validation; instructor-facing material
  • Performed by: QA Tester and/or Instructional Design

docs.title: 🔎 QA Reviewing Updates
docs.text:
• When: After change requests are implemented
  • Purpose: Confirm requested updates were implemented correctly
  • Scope: requested items, formatting consistency, effects on course flow

docs.title: 🧭 Course Orientation
docs.text:
• [ ] Syllabus present, accessible, up to date
  • [ ] Welcome/Getting Started page available
  • [ ] Course schedule/calendar accurate
  • [ ] Contact info and communication policy provided
  • [ ] Course policies align with institutional guidelines

docs.title: 🧱 Modules & Content
docs.text:
• [ ] Clear, consistent module titles (naming conventions)
  • [ ] Learning objectives at top of each module or clearly accessible
  • [ ] Readable formatting (headings, bullets, spacing)
  • [ ] No placeholder/template text
  • [ ] Videos and links function correctly
  • [ ] Readings/media relevant to objectives

docs.title: 🧪 Assessments
docs.text:
• [ ] Instructions are clear
  • [ ] Rubrics attached where applicable
  • [ ] Due dates correctly set and consistent with syllabus/schedule
  • [ ] Tests/quizzes published with correct settings
  • [ ] Submission methods functional and LMS-compatible

docs.title: ♿ Accessibility
docs.text:
• [ ] Alt text for all images (or marked decorative)
  • [ ] Tables use headers and proper structure
  • [ ] Color contrast meets WCAG 2.1
  • [ ] Logical heading hierarchy (H1 > H2 > H3)
  • [ ] PDFs/docs readable by screen readers

docs.title: 🧭 Navigation & Course Structure
docs.text:
• [ ] Clean, intuitive course menu; unused items removed
  • [ ] No placeholder links; all links work
  • [ ] Instructor-only/master-only materials removed from student view
  • [ ] No duplicated or over-nested content
  • [ ] Page titles match menu labels

docs.title: 🛠️ Technical Functionality
docs.text:
• [ ] LTI tools (Turnitin, Cengage, Panopto, etc.) properly embedded
  • [ ] Interactive content loads correctly
  • [ ] Gradebook columns align with assignments
  • [ ] No broken HTML (iframes, embed tags, etc.)

docs.title: 📝 Assignment Review Criteria
docs.text:
1. Banner matches the activity type: Ensure visual/banner accurately reflects assignment.
  2. Directions are complete: Full sentences, clear, grammatical.
  3. All links work: Open in new tabs, no raw URLs.
  4. Due dates match syllabus: Cross-check with official syllabus.
  5. Rubrics are visible: Match syllabus, ordered high-to-low.
  6. Release conditions match syllabus: Check availability rules.
  7. Be concise: Only report if change is required.

docs.title: 💬 Discussion Review Criteria
docs.text:
1. Banner matches activity type.
  2. Directions use complete sentences.
  3. All links work, open in separate tabs.

  4. Due dates match syllabus (Exception: Medical Science).

  5. Rubrics visible, match syllabus, descending order.

  6. Release conditions align with syllabus.
  7. Be concise.

docs.title: 🧩 Correct Answer Alignment (Assessments)
docs.text:
• Question text matches document exactly.
  • Answer options match content/order (unless randomized).
  • "EXCEPT"/"NOT" questions marked correctly.
  • Correct answer text matches document exactly (ignore letter labels if text matches).
  • Question type matches document.
  • Formatting preserved.

docs.title: ✍️ Grammar, Style, and Consistency QA Checklist
docs.text:
• Grammar: Full sentences, agreement, tense.
  • Tone: Clear, instructional, professional.
  • Clarity: Specific, actionable steps.
  • Objective phrasing: "By the end of this module..."
  • QA Tags: #GrammarIssue, #InconsistentTone, #RedundantText, #TimeZoneConflict, #ClarityNeeded, #CapitalizationInconsistency

docs.title: 🧭 Content Issues Index
docs.text:
• Orientation: Duplicate Syllabus Link, Placeholder Welcome Message
  • Module Content: Missing Learning Objectives, Inconsistent Heading Levels, Broken/Empty Links
  • Assessment: Vague Assignment Instructions, Missing Rubric, Quiz Not Published
  • Accessibility: Missing Alt Text, Low Color Contrast, Heading Skips
  • Technical: LMS Tool Not Loading, Incorrect Gradebook Setup

docs.title: 📅 Due Date Validation: Placeholder Dates
docs.text:
• Ignore: Far-future placeholder dates (e.g., 1/2/2035) unless they conflict with syllabus or have incorrect time.
  • Acceptable: "Due date is 1/2/35; time is Sunday at 11:55 PM. Placeholder acceptable in unpublished shells."

docs.title: � Avoiding False Positives
docs.text:
• Placeholder Dates: Ignore if aligned with iPlan/schedule.
  • Rubric Availability: Ignore if embedded in Gradebook/Overview.
  • Missing/Unused Visuals: Ignore if design doesn't call for them.
  • Learning Objectives: Ignore if listed in Course Overview/Syllabus.

docs.title: Student QA Checklist
docs.text: Goal: Verify the course is student-ready by checking navigation, content visibility, and link validity.

docs.title: 1. Course Info & Orientation
docs.text:
• [ ] Course Code: Verify it matches the header and banner.
  • [ ] Banner: Ensure image matches the course title/code.
  • [ ] Start Here / Orientation Module:
    • [ ] Must be visible to students.
    • [ ] Contains "Student Resources" (or Program Resources).
    • [ ] Contains clear instructions for getting started.
  • [ ] Syllabus:
    • [ ] Link is valid and opens the correct document.
    • [ ] Header info (Code/Name) is correct.
    • [ ] No "Track Changes" or visible comments.
    • [ ] Format is clean and professional.
  • [ ] Acknowledgement: "Course Orientation Acknowledgement" test exists.

docs.title: 2. Modules & Navigation
docs.text:
• [ ] Visibility: All learning modules are set to "Visible to students".
  • [ ] Release Conditions: Verify any conditional releases are set up correctly.
  • [ ] Tabs:
    • [ ] Discussions: Topics follow a sequential order (e.g., "Introductions" -> "Module 1" -> "Module 2"...).
    • [ ] Gradebook: Columns are organized chronologically (by due date) or sequentially (Module 1 -> Module 15).
    • [ ] Groups: Self-enrollment groups are set up (if applicable).

docs.title: 3. Content Checks (Assignments, Discussions, Tests, Journals)
docs.text: For every item type found in the course: - [ ] Banner: Matches the activity type. - [ ] Instructions: Clear guidelines provided. - [ ] Rubric: Attached, visible to students, and matches SharePoint files. - [ ] Links/Attachments: - [ ] Open in a new tab (target="_blank"). - [ ] No "raw" URLs (e.g., https://...) visible in text. - [ ] All links are valid (no 404s).

docs.title: 4. Final Wrap-up
docs.text:
• [ ] Tracking List: Update status to "SQA findings".
  • [ ] Time Log: Record time spent on QA.

docs.title: TQA Advice & Preparation Guide
docs.text:
TQA (Term Quality Assurance) is the phase where Instructional Designers and Faculty prepare the course before it reaches the Student QA (SQA) team.

The goal of TQA is to ensure the course is "structurally sound" so SQA can focus on fine-tuning the student experience rather than fixing broken foundations.

docs.title: 🎯 The "Pre-SQA" Checklist
docs.text: Before you mark a course as ready for SQA, please verify these "Big 5" items. These are the most common reasons for SQA kickbacks.

docs.title: 1. Dates, Dates, Dates
docs.text:
• System Dates: Ensure the Course Start/End dates in the LMS settings are correct for the upcoming term.
  • Due Dates: Run a bulk edit or quick scan. Are there any dates from 2023 or 2024 lingering?
  • Release Conditions: Check that "Start Here" and "Module 1" are actually visible on the start date.

docs.title: 2. The Gradebook Schema
docs.text:
• Total Points: Does the total match the syllabus? (e.g., if Syallbus says 1000 points, does Gradebook show 1005?)
  • Weighted Columns: If using weights, do they add up to 100%?
  • Zeros: Are "Treat ungraded items as 0" settings consistent?

docs.title: 3. Broken Links (The "Click Test")
docs.text:
• External Tools: Click every LTI link (Cengage, Zoom, Panopto). These often break during course copy.
  • Files: unexpected permission errors on Google Drive/SharePoint links are common.

docs.title: 4. Duplicate Content
docs.text:
• Course Copy often creates duplicates (e.g., "Syllabus (1)", "Copy of Final Exam").
  • Action: Delete the old versions. Do not just hide them.

docs.title: 5. Placeholder Removal
docs.text:
• Scan for "[INSERT DATE HERE]" or "Instructor Name".
  • Update the "Welcome" announcement.

docs.title: 1. Use the "Student View"
docs.text: Don't just look at the course in Edit mode. Enter Student Preview and try to submit the first assignment. If you can't, the students can't.

docs.title: 2. Check the "Hidden" folders
docs.text: Sometimes content is inside a folder that is hidden. Even if the item says "Visible", if the parent folder is "Hidden", students won't see it.

docs.title: 3. Update the Syllabus First
docs.text: The Syllabus is the "source of truth" for SQA. If you change a due date or an assignment name in Blackboard, update the Syllabus document immediately. SQA will flag a defect if they don't match.

docs.title: 🚀 Ready for SQA?
docs.text: Once you have checked these items: 1. Set the course status to "Ready for SQA" (or equivalent). 2. Notify the SQA team. 3. Relax! You've caught the big bugs.
